summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons Program Statement (P6541.02) establishing procedures for inmate access to Over-the-Counter (OTC) medications. It details how inmates can purchase OTC medications from the commissary or obtain them for free if indigent, and outlines the roles of health services and commissary staff in managing this program.

keyFacts: This document is a Bureau of Prisons policy (P6541.02) on inmate access to Over-the-Counter medications, dated November 17, 2004.

The policy allows inmates to purchase OTC medications from the commissary and establishes procedures for indigent inmates (those without a $6.00 trust fund balance for 30 days) to receive them for free from the pharmacy.
The document rescinds a previous directive (P6541.01) from September 10, 2003, indicating an update to the OTC medication program.
It specifies that institutions must stock at least 25 OTC medications and lists examples of minor ailments (e.g., constipation, allergies, acne) for which inmates would be referred to the commissary.
The policy includes an attachment listing specific 'medically-necessary' OTC medications (e.g., Acetaminophen, Aspirin, Hydrocortisone Cream) that must be supplied to indigent inmates.
